episode_title: How This Mom Built a 7-Figure Business from Home and How You Can Too with Jayne Havens
transcript:
ï»¿Nikolas Hulewsky (00:01.667)
All right, Jane, excited to have you. If you would, I know you've given it a million times, but tell me about your business and how you make money.


Jayne (00:11.246)
Sure. First of all, thank you so much for having me. I'm really excited to be on your podcast. My name's Jane Havens. I'm from Baltimore, Maryland. I grew up here. I live here as an adult. It's fantastic. I have two kids and I'm married and I run a sleep consulting business. I support parents through the process of teaching their little ones to sleep independently and through the night. When I first started working in this field, I was supporting primarily families with infants.


three, four, five, six month old babies. And over the years, my business has shifted a little bit. Now I work with toddlers and preschoolers primarily, three, four, five year olds, which I love. It's really meaningful work. sort of marries sleep consulting and parent coaching together because I really help parents to set limits with their children. I call it loving limits or respectful boundaries. And I do this work entirely virtually. So,


My clients are all up and down the East Coast and some, you know, in other parts of the world, but primarily New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, and I'm in Baltimore. So, you know, I don't have to physically be there to help them. All of my work is done by text message and email and, you know, all the good stuff. So it's really, it's really special.


Nikolas Hulewsky (01:30.723)
me set some context. Quickly, tell me what year did you start the business and then this year, let's say 2024, how big is the business in terms of revenue, number of employees, maybe number of families helped. I don't know what other metrics you might use.


Jayne (01:43.916)
Yeah, sure. So I started business, my business in 2018. And I think it was actually really the end of 2018. So my first full year in business was 2019. That year, I think I did like $56,000 in revenue, which I was really proud of. It was my first year in business. My business was intended to be a side hustle and it very quickly was like a very legitimate business and something that I was really excited about. Year two, I think I doubled it.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:02.191)
Yeah.


Jayne (02:13.774)
And then after that, I actually launched my sleep consultant certification program. So my income increased drastically from there. But if we're just talking sleep consulting revenue, I think I do about $8,000 to $10,000 a month-ish. And it's been, yeah, it's been pretty consistent for the past couple of years. I have...


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:32.751)
Okay, so let's say 120-ish.


Jayne (02:40.61)
I've sort of gotten into this steady flow of I'm not spending a whole ton of time marketing my business anymore. I've been doing this for enough years where most of my business just comes to me word of mouth, friends of friends, friends of former clients. And so it's, it's pretty steady.


Nikolas Hulewsky (02:56.815)
And the agency, how big is the agency?

So it's not an agency, it's an online training program. So I don't actually have contractors working under me. I just teach people how to do this work and then they go and start their own businesses. Last year, my total revenue was like $750,000 or something like that. Pretty cool, right? Like I literally sit at my kitchen table, I wear leggings and a sweatshirt.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:18.703)
It's amazing. Yeah.


Jayne (03:25.934)
and like barely ever put a face of makeup on and run my business from my phone and my iPad. And, you know, I crack open my computer every now and then. And I have a pretty legitimate business, which is so crazy. Yeah. It's legit. Yeah. Pretty cool.


Nikolas Hulewsky (03:39.407)
Not a pretty, you don't need to qualify pretty, it's legitimate. You have a seven figure business teaching people how to sleep basically. teach them how to Okay, that's amazing. Thank you for setting the context for me. Help me understand. You said you went from infants, which makes total sense to me. We've had five children. So I'm very familiar with the sleeping training. But you said you go from infants to toddlers? Like what does the ideal customer look like? Or what is a typical


I don't know, parent, customer look like when they come to you, what's their problem set?


Jayne (04:13.164)
Yeah, so almost all of the families that I work with, regardless of their child's age, they all have the same struggle. They have a child that either doesn't know how to or is seemingly unwilling to fall asleep without support, right? So little infants, know, four or five, six month old babies, they literally don't know how to fall asleep unless a parent is helping them because that's just always the way that they've done it. So


you know, their entire lives, their tiny short little lives, they've been fed to sleep, they've been rocked to sleep, they've been pushed in a stroller or driven in a car to fall asleep, and they don't know how to get their bodies to fall asleep without that support. So we literally teach them how to do it. We give them an opportunity to try. With older kiddos, you know, two, three, four-year-olds, most of them,


were falling asleep independently at some point and something happened, whether it was sickness or travel or separation anxiety kicked in or something scared them and it led them to no longer feel comfortable falling asleep without help from a parent. And for three and four year olds, that generally looks like a parent sitting in the room with the child while they fall asleep, rubbing their back.


Sometimes it's not always the parent helping them fall asleep. I've worked with kids who want to listen to their Tony box or they want all the lights on or they need to watch their iPad to fall asleep, all sorts of stuff. And the problem with that is that when a child requires support or accommodations to fall asleep at bedtime, then when their bodies rouse awake in the middle of the night, which like that happens to all humans, it's just normal human behavior.


But when our bodies rouse awake in the middle of the night, they're expecting that same support or those same accommodations. And we really want to get kids to a place where they can just lie down in their bed and close their eyes and let their bodies relax. And next thing they know, they're asleep. And so that when they rouse awake, they can do that in the middle of the night again.


Nikolas Hulewsky (06:23.501)
And why would a parent come to you? Are they like, can't sleep through the night? Or are they worried that their child isn't falling asleep by themselves? And so it's more about what concerns your child.


Jayne (06:32.364)
Well, what happens is these parents are up all night with their kids because if they're helping them to fall asleep at seven or eight o'clock at night, they pop awake at 1030, they pop awake at 12, they pop awake at two and four and six. And so they're up all night long needing help getting back to sleep. And so these parents are exhausted. And the primary reason that I would say parents come to me for support is because kids cry when we work on it. And...


There's a lot of negativity in this current climate of parenting when it comes to kids crying. Parents have a lot of guilt around their kids being upset and it's really sort of triggering to them. It's raising their blood pressure, their cortisol is soaring and frankly they feel like bad parents because they can't get it straight. And so hiring a sleep consultant or a parent coach


really positions them to have accountability and support and to have like a really clear process for how to go about improving the situation.


Nikolas Hulewsky (07:37.849)
I want you to talk to this hypothetical man who's 39 years old, that has a four year old, that he lets fall asleep with him every night. Why is that bad? Okay.

It's not, it's not bad. It's not, does your four, is this year a four year old? Okay. Yeah.

four year old. I met him before we started Robbie. Oops, Mohammed, take that name out, please. But I just I can't he was born during COVID. He's a COVID baby. And I just look at him and I'm like, you're growing up so fast. And I, I just tell stories with him. We talk with whatever until he falls asleep. And I enjoy it. But he doesn't wake up in the middle of the night. And he doesn't come into our room.


Jayne (08:20.386)
Yeah, yeah, so there's no problem. Right. Yeah, right, so that's fine. That's fine if that, first of all, I always say, like, if you're helping your kids to sleep either at bedtime or in the middle of the night, and if that's working for you, then like, no problem. Parents come to me because it's not working for them. Like, either bedtime is taking two hours and their children are stalling and, you know, mom has to...


make lunches for the next day or needs to get back onto the computer to get some work done. You know, if that bedtime routine is no longer working for you and you're no longer enjoying it and you're starting to dread bedtime because it's taking forever, then I would empower you to feel confident to make a change. But if you feel like it's a beautiful time and you're connecting and you love it and it's cuddly and you're sleeping through the night, then like, amazing. It sounds sounds beautiful.


Nikolas Hulewsky (09:14.863)
Can you tell my wife that? So I really love the way that your business started because you found a real problem that you're now solving. mean, parents have been struggling with bedtime for years and generations. And now we have a generation that doesn't like the kids to cry. please teach me how to make my kid not cry when I put them to bed. It's interesting though that you've gone from doing it really well

Yeah, she'll listen, right?

building this train the trainer model. And I love it because it allows you to scale. And I think that it's really smart. But can we go back to the beginning? When did you realize this could be a proper business because you haven't always been doing sleep training?

All right, yeah, so I have a former background in catering sales, actually. I used to be an event planner. I was really creative. I'm a foodie. No, I worked for a big catering company in Washington, DC.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:22.841)
Was it your company? Okay.

But I was operating almost like an independent business owner. I had a lot of agency. I was my own salesperson. And I kept track of my own budgets and where I had extra money to spend and where I need it. I was really, it wasn't entrepreneurial, but yeah, but it was good training for the work that I do now.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:53.231)
You got some good training.

especially from like a customer service aspect, like, right? Like when you're working in catering, the, the customer is always right. And I was home with my son for four years and I loved it. It was, it was a really special time.


Nikolas Hulewsky (10:59.897)
Yeah.

When my daughter was born, stay at home mom life all of a sudden got really, really challenging. She was colicky. She had a milk soy protein intolerance. She was literally crying all the time. And I was like, I gotta get a job. I gotta get out of here. And so I kept thinking, what can I do to use my brain, earn some money, feel like a highly functioning individual again without...


putting my kids in daycare without hiring a nanny. I really still felt like I wanted to be the primary caregiver, but I wanted to like get back to work. And I was always really good at getting my own kids to sleep. Like I figured it out with them at a really early age, both of them. And I was the one who, you know, my friends were asking me for help and then their friends would reach out to me and ask for help. I literally did this work for free, I think for like four or five years before I actually realized.

entrepreneur.

care either way. I think because I think it's fun. And so I don't have all of these things holding me back that I see a lot of aspiring entrepreneurs have in their minds.
